macro.para:
This macro transforms seq into the special form illustrated by the following pseudo-code:
(, seq[0])() (, seq[1])() ... (, seq[length(seq) - 1])() (, def)
In particular, each element of seq is converted to a binary element with as the first sub-element and the original element as the second sub-element. Each of the binary elements is suffixed with nullary parentheses, and the entire result of all such transformations is suffixed with a binary element with as the first sub-element and def or __VA_ARGS__ as the second sub-element.

This form facilitates where each implies "continue" and the implies "stop". The nullary parentheses after each element makes it easy to use a single macro and an indirection macro to perform rather than two near identical macros that otherwise would be required. For example,
#define A(seq) B((seq, ~)) #define B(bin) C bin #define C(m, elem) m(1)(<elem> C_INDIRECT) #define C_INDIRECT() C
A((a)(b)(c)(d)) // <a> <b> <c> <d>
This macro uses . As a result, the algorithm is theoretically capable of processing an infinite number of elements.
